Subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to write the assertion?


> As an example, using the Agile method (scrums, sprints) where
> a sprint of 28 days is in place code is not ready for testing
> until maybe the 21 day.

Did you actually experience this?
[Bob Bondi] Every day at my current work site.

As far as I know, Scrum doesn't say much about testing (or coding) at
all -
which is way many teams adopt XP practices for this part of the process.


XP, on the other hand, *requires* that the customer representative
expresses
the requirements in executable (QA style) acceptance tests, which need
to be
ready at the end of the iteration (sprint). It also encourages
developers to
produce fully working, integrated and unit tested code from day one.

So I'm not sure where your impression is coming from; to me it doesn't
sound
like a team where that can happen really has groked Agile software
development.


> In my experience the project managers
> for sprints do not understand the need for engineering specs,
> hence they do not exist, or if they do they are after the
> fact.

I'm not sure what you mean by "engineering specs", but I also don't
understand why the project manager has to understand their need for them
to
be produced at the right time. It's the responsibility of the team to
produce what is needed when it's needed.
[Bob Bondi] Engineering specs derive from product requirements. A simple
example is the login screen.
A requirement states users must login in to the system.
An engineer codes for that case as well as the bad username or bad
password or the forgotten password.
This simple case is a 3 to 1 fan out of the requirement. In more complex
code the fanouts are not
discussed in engineering requirements. The QA team has no clue (in some
cases) how to properly test.
Good whitebox can overcome this but you bump into short sprints and the
time to whitebox is not there.

> There is no time in the plan for rework of bad code.

If you need time in the plan for rework, you are not doing enough of it.
Refactoring, as we call reworking code in small very controlled steps,
should be part of the developers minute-to-minute work. They should be
doing
so much of it, so tightly intermingled with the rest of their work, that
it's impossible to measure how much of their time they are spending
doing
it.

> There is no time in the sprint for rigorous QA.

QA should be an ongoing effort during the sprint, parallel to the rest
of
the work. If there is "no time" for this, the team really is not a truly
Agile one.
[Bob Bondi] This assumes the team delivers code that can be tested
beyond Unit testing. If so, I agree.

> This leads to quantity not quality.

Agreed. But it has nothing to do with Agility.
[Bob Bondi] I'll be on the back burner for awhile watching how this
process works. I do not want to
become reactionary about it, only to be 'agile' enough to really provide
the testing customers demand
prior to receiving products.

> Remember that satellite that crashed in the
> planet Mars because different methods of measuring speed were
> used. Effective integration testing would have caught that problem.

As would have better communication and collaboration. That hardly was an
Agile project, was it? ;)
[Bob Bondi] communication and collaboration: my points exactly restated
so eloquently!

Cheers, Ilja
[Bob Bondi] Back at ya :)
